snippet: Germany, France and Italy said that they would be part of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which Washington views as a rival to the World Bank.
abstract: Germany, France and Italy announce they will follow Britain and join Chinese-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, over objections made by United States; decision is likely to help Chinese Pres XI Jinping's efforts to alter global balance of power, and raises possibility that World Bank and International Monetary Fund will diminish in influence.

byline.original: By ANDREW HIGGINS and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Andrew Higgins reported from Brussels, and David E. Sanger from Washington. David Jolly contributed reporting from Paris, and Michael Forsythe from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: Germany, France and Italy said that they would be part of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which Washington views as a rival to the World Bank.

headline.main: 3 European Powers Say They Will Join China-Led Bank
headline.print_headline: 3 European Powers Say They Will Join China-Led Bank
